macports, virtualenv, pip, macvim, terminal

Homebrew is awesome because it uses as much as possible of the existing tools / libraries already present on Mac OS X. Also every package version is installed into its own directory and symlinked from there into the respective system folder (e.g. /usr/bin) - this makes removing stuff much easier.
I think Steve Losh's blog post is a very good description of a Django development environment http://stevelosh.com/blog/2011/06/django-advice/

I've been using macports for anything requiring c-library support (db drivers, PIL, lxml, gevent) and virtualenv+pip for everything else. I use IntelliJ Ultimate for my IDE. The Python plugin lags behind PyCharm, but you get many other languages supported too (PHP, ActionScript, Java, Lua, etc.). I've used Pythonbrew a little in CentOS and was very impressed.
